built with pdoc

sain

sain is a set of minimal abstraction that brings Rust's ecosystem to Python. It offers a few of the core Rust features like Vec<T> and Result<T, E> and more. See the equivalent type section below.

Equivalent types
  • Option<T> -> Option[T] | Some[T]
  • Result<T, E> -> Result[T, E]
  • &dyn Error -> Error
  • Vec<T> -> Vec[T]
  • Default<T> -> Default[T]
  • slice::Iter<Item> -> Iter[Item]
  • iter::Iterator<Item> -> Iterator[Item]
  • Box<T> -> Box[T], not a heap box.
  • cell::Cell<T> -> Cell[T], slightly different.
  • cell::RefCell<T> -> RefCell[T], slightly different.
  • sync::LazyLock<T> -> Lazy[T]
  • sync::OnceLock<T> -> Once[T]
  • mem::MaybeUninit<T> -> MaybeUninit[T]
Equivalent macros

As decorators.

  • cfg!() -> sain.cfg
  • todo!() -> sain.todo. This is not a decorator.
  • deprecated!() -> sain.deprecated
  • unimplemented!() -> sain.unimplemented
  • #[cfg_attr] -> sain.cfg_attr
  • #[doc()] -> sain.doc()

 31"""sain is a set of minimal abstraction that brings Rust's ecosystem to Python.
 32It offers a few of the core Rust features like `Vec<T>` and `Result<T, E>` and more.
 33See the equivalent type section below.
 34
 35Equivalent types
 36----------------
 37- `Option<T>` -> `Option[T]` | `Some[T]`
 38- `Result<T, E>` -> `Result[T, E]`
 39- `&dyn Error` -> `Error`
 40- `Vec<T>` -> `Vec[T]`
 41- `Default<T>` -> `Default[T]`
 42- `slice::Iter<Item>` -> `Iter[Item]`
 43- `iter::Iterator<Item>` -> `Iterator[Item]`
 44- `Box<T>` -> `Box[T]`, not a heap box.
 45- `cell::Cell<T>` -> `Cell[T]`, slightly different.
 46- `cell::RefCell<T>` -> `RefCell[T]`, slightly different.
 47- `sync::LazyLock<T>` -> `Lazy[T]`
 48- `sync::OnceLock<T>` -> `Once[T]`
 49- `mem::MaybeUninit<T>` -> `MaybeUninit[T]`
 50
 51Equivalent macros
 52-----------------
 53As decorators.
 54
 55- `cfg!()` -> `sain.cfg`
 56- `todo!()` -> `sain.todo`. This is not a decorator.
 57- `deprecated!()` -> `sain.deprecated`
 58- `unimplemented!()` -> `sain.unimplemented`
 59- `#[cfg_attr]` -> `sain.cfg_attr`
 60- `#[doc()]` -> `sain.doc()`

def cfg( target_os: Optional[Literal['linux', 'win32', 'darwin', 'unix', 'windows']] = None, requires: str | None = None, python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None, target_arch: Optional[Literal['x86', 'x64', 'arm', 'arm64']] = None, impl: Optional[Literal['CPython', 'PyPy', 'IronPython', 'Jython']] = None) -> bool: 
186def cfg(
187    target_os: System | None = None,
188    requires: str | None = None,
189    python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None,
190    target_arch: Arch | None = None,
191    impl: Python | None = None,
192) -> bool:
193    """A function that will run the code only if all predicate attributes returns `True`.
194
195    .. warning::
196        The `requires` parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation and will be removed in a future release.
197        Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.
198
199    The difference between this function and `cfg_attr` is that this function will not raise an exception.
200    Instead it will return `False` if any of the attributes fails.
201
202    Example
203    -------
204    ```py
205    import sain
206
207    if sain.cfg(target_os="windows"):
208        print("Windows")
209    elif sain.cfg(target_os="linux"):
210        print("Linux")
211    else:
212        print("Something else")
213    ```
214
215    Parameters
216    ----------
217    requires : `str | None`
218        A required module to run the object.
219    target_os : `str | None`
220        The targeted operating system thats required for the object to be ran.
221    python_version : `tuple[int, int, int] | None`
222        The targeted Python version thats required for the object to be ran. Format must be `(3, 9, 5)``
223    target_arch : `str | None`
224        The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object to be ran.
225    impl : `str | None`
226        The Python implementation thats required for the object to be ran.
227
228    Returns
229    -------
230    `bool`
231        The condition that was checked.
232    """
233    checker = _AttrCheck(
234        lambda: None,
235        no_raise=True,
236        requires=requires,
237        target_os=target_os,
238        python_version=python_version,
239        target_arch=target_arch,
240        impl=impl,
241    )
242    return checker.internal_check()

A function that will run the code only if all predicate attributes returns True.

The requires parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation and will be removed in a future release. Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.

The difference between this function and cfg_attr is that this function will not raise an exception. Instead it will return False if any of the attributes fails.

Example
import sain

if sain.cfg(target_os="windows"):
    print("Windows")
elif sain.cfg(target_os="linux"):
    print("Linux")
else:
    print("Something else")
Parameters
  • requires (str | None): A required module to run the object.
  • target_os (str | None): The targeted operating system thats required for the object to be ran.
  • python_version (tuple[int, int, int] | None): The targeted Python version thats required for the object to be ran. Format must be `(3, 9, 5)``
  • target_arch (str | None): The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object to be ran.
  • impl (str | None): The Python implementation thats required for the object to be ran.
Returns
  • bool: The condition that was checked.
def cfg_attr( *, requires: str | None = None, target_os: Optional[Literal['linux', 'win32', 'darwin', 'unix', 'windows']] = None, python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None, target_arch: Optional[Literal['x86', 'x64', 'arm', 'arm64']] = None, impl: Optional[Literal['CPython', 'PyPy', 'IronPython', 'Jython']] = None) -> collections.abc.Callable[[~F], ~F]: 
102def cfg_attr(
103    *,
104    requires: str | None = None,
105    target_os: System | None = None,
106    python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None,
107    target_arch: Arch | None = None,
108    impl: Python | None = None,
109) -> collections.Callable[[F], F]:
110    """Conditional runtime object configuration based on passed arguments.
111
112    If the decorated object gets called and one of the attributes returns `False`,
113    `RuntimeError` will be raised and the object will not run.
114
115    .. warning::
116        The `requires` parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation
117        and will be removed in a future release.
118        Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.
119
120    Example
121    -------
122    ```py
123    import sain
124
125    @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="windows")
126    def windows_only():
127        # Do stuff with Windows's API.
128        ...
129
130    # Mut be PyPy Python implementation or `RuntimeError` will be raised
131    # when creating the instance.
132    @sain.cfg_attr(impl="PyPy")
133    class Zoo:
134        @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="linux")
135        def bark(self) -> None:
136            windows_only()  # RuntimeError("Windows OS only!)
137
138    # An instance will not be created if raised.
139    zoo = Zoo()
140    # RuntimeError("class Zoo requires PyPy implementation")
141    zoo.bark()
142    # Whats zoo??
143    ```
144
145    Parameters
146    ----------
147    requires : `str | None`
148        A required module to run the object.
149    target_os : `str | None`
150        The targeted operating system thats required for the object.
151    python_version : `tuple[int, int, int] | None`
152        The targeted Python version thats required for the object. Format must be `(3, 9, 5)`.
153    target_arch : `str | None`
154        The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object.
155    impl : `str | None`
156        The Python implementation thats required for the object.
157
158    Raises
159    ------
160    `RuntimeError`
161        This fails if any of the attributes returns `False`. `required_modules` is not included.
162    `ModuleNotFoundError`
163        If the module check fails. i.e., if `required_modules` was provided and it returns `False`.
164    `ValueError`
165        If the passed Python implementation is unknown.
166    """
167
168    def decorator(callback: F) -> F:
169        @functools.wraps(callback)
170        def wrapper(*args: typing.Any, **kwargs: typing.Any) -> F:
171            checker = _AttrCheck(
172                callback,
173                requires=requires,
174                target_os=target_os,
175                python_version=python_version,
176                target_arch=target_arch,
177                impl=impl,
178            )
179            return checker(*args, **kwargs)
180
181        return typing.cast(F, wrapper)
182
183    return decorator

Conditional runtime object configuration based on passed arguments.

If the decorated object gets called and one of the attributes returns False, RuntimeError will be raised and the object will not run.

The requires parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation and will be removed in a future release. Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.

Example
import sain

@sain.cfg_attr(target_os="windows")
def windows_only():
    # Do stuff with Windows's API.
    ...

# Mut be PyPy Python implementation or `RuntimeError` will be raised
# when creating the instance.
@sain.cfg_attr(impl="PyPy")
class Zoo:
    @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="linux")
    def bark(self) -> None:
        windows_only()  # RuntimeError("Windows OS only!)

# An instance will not be created if raised.
zoo = Zoo()
# RuntimeError("class Zoo requires PyPy implementation")
zoo.bark()
# Whats zoo??
Parameters
  • requires (str | None): A required module to run the object.
  • target_os (str | None): The targeted operating system thats required for the object.
  • python_version (tuple[int, int, int] | None): The targeted Python version thats required for the object. Format must be (3, 9, 5).
  • target_arch (str | None): The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object.
  • impl (str | None): The Python implementation thats required for the object.
Raises
  • RuntimeError: This fails if any of the attributes returns False. required_modules is not included.
  • ModuleNotFoundError: If the module check fails. i.e., if required_modules was provided and it returns False.
  • ValueError: If the passed Python implementation is unknown.
@typing.runtime_checkable
class Default(typing.Protocol[+_T_co]): 
57@typing.runtime_checkable
58class Default(typing.Protocol[_T_co]):
59    """An interface for an object that has a default value.
60
61    Example
62    -------
63    ```py
64    from sain import Default
65
66    class Cache(Default[dict[str, Any]]):
67
68        @staticmethod
69        def default() -> dict[str, Any]:
70            return {}
71
72    cache = Cache.default()
73    print(cache)
74    assert isinstance(cache, Default)
75    # {}
76    ```
77    """
78
79    __slots__ = ()
80
81    @staticmethod
82    def default() -> _T_co:
83        """Return the default value of the object."""
84        raise NotImplementedError

An interface for an object that has a default value.

Example
from sain import Default

class Cache(Default[dict[str, Any]]):

    @staticmethod
    def default() -> dict[str, Any]:
        return {}

cache = Cache.default()
print(cache)
assert isinstance(cache, Default)
# {}
Default(*args, **kwargs) 
1430def _no_init_or_replace_init(self, *args, **kwargs):
1431    cls = type(self)
1432
1433    if cls._is_protocol:
1434        raise TypeError('Protocols cannot be instantiated')
1435
1436    # Already using a custom `__init__`. No need to calculate correct
1437    # `__init__` to call. This can lead to RecursionError. See bpo-45121.
1438    if cls.__init__ is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1439        return
1440
1441    # Initially, `__init__` of a protocol subclass is set to `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1442    # The first instantiation of the subclass will call `_no_init_or_replace_init` which
1443    # searches for a proper new `__init__` in the MRO. The new `__init__`
1444    # replaces the subclass' old `__init__` (ie `_no_init_or_replace_init`). Subsequent
1445    # instantiation of the protocol subclass will thus use the new
1446    # `__init__` and no longer call `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1447    for base in cls.__mro__:
1448        init = base.__dict__.get('__init__', _no_init_or_replace_init)
1449        if init is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1450            cls.__init__ = init
1451            break
1452    else:
1453        # should not happen
1454        cls.__init__ = object.__init__
1455
1456    cls.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
@staticmethod
def default() -> +_T_co: 
81    @staticmethod
82    def default() -> _T_co:
83        """Return the default value of the object."""
84        raise NotImplementedError

Return the default value of the object.

@typing.final
class Some(typing.Generic[~T], sain.Default[NoneType]): 
 55@typing.final
 56class Some(typing.Generic[T], _default.Default[None]):
 57    """The `Option` type. An object that might be `T` or `None`.
 58
 59    It is a drop-in replacement for `typing.Optional[T]`, But has proper methods to handle the contained value.
 60
 61    Example
 62    -------
 63    ```py
 64    value = Some("Hello")
 65    print(value)
 66    # Some("Hello")
 67
 68    # This will unwrap the contained value as long as
 69    # it is not `None` otherwise this will raise an error.
 70    print(value.unwrap())
 71    # "Hello"
 72
 73    none_value = Some(None)
 74    while none_value.unwrap():
 75        # Never unreachable!
 76
 77    # Solving it with `unwrap_or` method to unwrap the value or return a default value.
 78    print(none_value.unwrap_or(10))
 79    # 10
 80    ```
 81    """
 82
 83    __slots__ = ("_value",)
 84
 85    def __init__(self, value: T | None, /) -> None:
 86        self._value = value
 87
 88    @staticmethod
 89    def default() -> None:
 90        """Default value for `Some`. Returns `None`."""
 91        return None
 92
 93    # *- Reading the value -*
 94
 95    def into_inner(self) -> T | None:
 96        """Consume `Self`, returning the wrapped value as `T | None`.
 97
 98        Examples
 99        --------
100        ```py
101        opt = Some('char')
102        x = opt.into_inner()
103        assert x is not None
104
105        opt = Some(None)
106        assert opt.into_inner() is None
107        ```
108        """
109        return self._value
110
111    def unwrap(self) -> T:
112        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or raising a `RuntimeError`.
113
114        Example
115        -------
116        ```py
117        value = Some(5)
118        print(value.unwrap())
119        # 5
120
121        value = Some(None)
122        print(value.unwrap())
123        # RuntimeError
124        ```
125
126        Raises
127        ------
128        `RuntimeError`
129            If the inner value is `None`.
130        """
131        if self._value is None:
132            raise RuntimeError(
133                f"Called `Option.unwrap()` on {type(self._value).__name__}."
134            ) from None
135
136        return self._value
137
138    def unwrap_or(self, default: T, /) -> T:
139        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or returning `default`.
140
141        Example
142        -------
143        ```py
144        value = Some(5)
145        print(value.unwrap_or(10))
146        # 5
147
148        # Type hint is required here.
149        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
150        print(value.unwrap_or(10))
151        # 10
152        ```
153        """
154        if self._value is None:
155            return default
156
157        return self._value
158
159    def unwrap_or_else(self, f: FnOnce[T], /) -> T:
160        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or calling `f` to get a default value.
161
162        Example
163        -------
164        ```py
165        value = Some(5)
166        print(value.unwrap_or_else(lambda: 10))
167        # 5
168
169        value: Option[bool] = Some(None)
170        print(value.unwrap_or_else(lambda: True))
171        # True
172        ```
173        """
174        if self._value is None:
175            return f()
176
177        return self._value
178
179    @macros.unsafe
180    def unwrap_unchecked(self) -> T:
181        """Unwrap the inner value immediately returning it.
182
183        Example
184        -------
185        ```py
186        v: Option[float] = Some(1.2)
187        v.unwrap_unchecked() # 1.2
188
189        v: Option[float] = Some(None)
190        print(v.unwrap_unchecked()) # Undefined Behavior
191        ```
192        """
193        #! SAFETY: The caller guarantees that the value is not None.
194        return self._value  # type: ignore
195
196    def expect(self, message: str, /) -> T:
197        """Returns the contained value if it is not `None` otherwise raises a `RuntimeError`.
198
199        Example
200        -------
201        ```py
202        value = Some("Hello")
203
204        print(value.expect("Value is None"))
205        # "Hello"
206
207        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
208        print(value.expect("Value is None"))
209        # RuntimeError("Value is None")
210        ```
211        """
212        if self._value is None:
213            raise RuntimeError(message)
214
215        return self._value
216
217    # *- Functional operations -*
218    def map(self, f: Fn[T, U], /) -> Some[U]:
219        """Map the inner value to another type. Returning `Some(None)` if `T` is `None`.
220
221        Example
222        -------
223        ```py
224        value = Some(5.0)
225
226        print(value.map(lambda x: x * 2.0))
227        # Some(10.0)
228
229        value: Option[bool] = Some(None)
230        print(value)
231        # Some(None)
232        ```
233        """
234        if self._value is None:
235            return nothing_unchecked()
236
237        return Some(f(self._value))
238
239    def map_or(self, default: U, f: Fn[T, U], /) -> U:
240        """Map the inner value to another type or return `default` if its `None`.
241
242        Example
243        -------
244        ```py
245        value: Option[float] = Some(5.0)
246
247        # map to int.
248        print(value.map_or(0, int))
249        # 6
250
251        value: Option[float] = Some(None)
252        print(value.map_or(0, int)
253        # 0
254        ```
255        """
256        if self._value is None:
257            return default
258
259        return f(self._value)
260
261    def map_or_else(self, default: FnOnce[U], f: Fn[T, U], /) -> U:
262        """Map the inner value to another type, or return `default()` if its `None`.
263
264        Example
265        -------
266        ```py
267        def default() -> int:
268            return sys.getsizeof(object())
269
270        value: Option[float] = Some(5.0)
271
272        # map to int.
273        print(value.map_or_else(default, int))
274        # 6
275
276        value: Option[float] = Some(None)
277        print(value.map_or_else(default, int)
278        # 28 <- size of object()
279        ```
280        """
281        if self._value is None:
282            return default()
283
284        return f(self._value)
285
286    def filter(self, predicate: Fn[T, bool]) -> Some[T]:
287        """Returns `Some(None)` if the contained value is `None`,
288
289        otherwise calls the predicate and returns `Some(T)` if the predicate returns `True`.
290
291        Example
292        -------
293        ```py
294        value = Some([1, 2, 3])
295
296        print(value.filter(lambda x: 1 in x))
297        # Some([1, 2, 3])
298
299        value: Option[int] = Some([1, 2, 3]) # or Some(None)
300        print(value.filter(lambda x: 1 not in x))
301        # None
302        ```
303        """
304        if (value := self._value) is not None:
305            if predicate(value):
306                return Some(value)
307
308        return nothing_unchecked()
309
310    # *- Inner operations *-
311
312    def take(self) -> Option[T]:
313        """Take the value from `Self`, Setting it to `None`.
314
315        Example
316        -------
317        ```py
318        original = Some("Hi")
319        new = original.take()
320
321        print(original, new)
322        # None, Some("Hi")
323        ```
324        """
325        if self._value is None:
326            return nothing_unchecked()
327
328        val = self._value
329        self._value = None
330        return Some(val)
331
332    def take_if(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[T], bool]) -> Option[T]:
333        """Take the value from `Self`, Setting it to `None` only if predicate returns `True`.
334
335        Example
336        -------
337        ```py
338        def validate(email: str) -> bool:
339            # you can obviously validate this better.
340            return email.find('@') == 1
341
342        original = Some("flex@gg.com")
343        valid = original.take_if(allowed)
344        assert is_allowed.is_some() and original.is_none()
345
346        original = Some("mail.example.com")
347        invalid = original.take_if(allowed)
348        assert invalid.is_none() and original.is_some()
349        ```
350        """
351        if self.map_or(False, predicate):
352            return self.take()
353
354        return nothing_unchecked()
355
356    def replace(self, value: T) -> Some[T]:
357        """Replace the contained value with another value.
358
359        Example
360        -------
361        ```py
362        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
363        value = value.replace("Hello")
364        # Some("Hello")
365        ```
366        """
367        self._value = value
368        return self
369
370    def and_ok(self, optb: Some[T]) -> Some[T]:
371        """Returns `Some(None)` if either contained value is `None`,
372
373        Otherwise return `optb`.
374
375        Example
376        -------
377        ```py
378        x: Option[int] = Some(None)
379        y: Option[str] = Some("bye")
380        assert x.and_ok(y).is_none()
381
382        x: Option[int] = Some(10)
383        y: Option[str] = Some("bye")
384        assert value.and_ok(y) == Some("bye")
385        ```
386        """
387        if self._value is None or optb.is_none():
388            return nothing_unchecked()
389
390        return optb
391
392    def and_then(self, f: Fn[T, Some[T]]) -> Some[T]:
393        """Returns `Some(None)` if the contained value is `None`, otherwise call `f()`
394        on `T` and return `Option[T]` if it's value not `None`.
395
396        Example
397        -------
398        ```py
399        value = Some(5)
400        print(value.and_then(lambda x: Some(x * 2)))
401        # Some(10)
402
403        value: Option[int] = Some(10)
404        print(value.and_then(lambda x: Some(None)))
405        # Some(None)
406        ```
407        """
408        if self._value is None:
409            return nothing_unchecked()
410
411        return f(self._value)
412
413    # *- Builder methods *-
414
415    def iter(self) -> iter.Iterator[T]:
416        """Returns an iterator over the contained value.
417
418        Example
419        -------
420        ```py
421        from sain import Some
422        value = Some("gg")
423        value.next() == Some("gg")
424
425        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
426        value.next().is_none()
427        ```
428        """
429        if self._value is None:
430            #! SAFETY: We know the value is None here.
431            return iter.empty()  # pyright: ignore
432
433        return iter.once(self._value)
434
435    def as_ref(self) -> Some[cell.Cell[T]]:
436        """Returns immutable `Some[sain.cell.Cell[T]]` if the contained value is not `None`,
437
438        Otherwise returns `Some(None)`.
439
440        Example
441        -------
442        ```py
443        value = Some(5).as_ref().unwrap()
444        value.object = 0 # FrozenError!
445
446        owned = value.object
447        print(owned) # 5
448
449        # Create a copy of object.
450        clone = value.copy()
451        clone = 0  # Thats fine.
452        print(clone == owned) # False, 0 != 5
453
454        # None object.
455        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
456        print(value.as_ref())
457        # Some(None)
458        ```
459
460        Raises
461        ------
462        `dataclasses.FrozenInstanceError`
463            When attempting to modify the contained value. Use `sain.AsRef.copy()` method to create a copy.
464
465            Or just use `.as_mut()` if you're dealing with mutable objects.
466        """
467        if self._value is not None:
468            return Some(cell.Cell(self._value))
469
470        # SAFETY: self._value is None.
471        return NOTHING  # pyright: ignore
472
473    def as_mut(self) -> Some[cell.RefCell[T]]:
474        """Returns mutable `Some[sain.cell.RefCell[T]]` if the contained value is not `None`,
475
476        Otherwise returns `Some(None)`.
477
478        Example
479        -------
480        ```py
481        value = Some(5).as_mut().unwrap()
482        value.object = 0
483        print(value) # Some(RefCell(0))
484
485        # None object.
486        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
487        print(value.as_mut())
488        # Some(None)
489        ```
490        """
491        if self._value is not None:
492            return Some(cell.RefCell(self._value))
493
494        # SAFETY: self._value is None.
495        return NOTHING  # pyright: ignore
496
497    # *- Boolean checks *-
498
499    def is_some(self) -> bool:
500        """Returns `True` if the contained value is not `None`, otherwise returns `False`.
501
502        Example
503        -------
504        ```py
505        value = Some(5)
506        print(value.is_some())
507        # True
508
509        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
510        print(value.is_some())
511        # False
512        ```
513        """
514        return self._value is not None
515
516    def is_some_and(self, predicate: Fn[T, bool]) -> bool:
517        """Returns `True` if the contained value is not `None` and
518        the predicate returns `True`, otherwise returns `False`.
519
520        Example
521        -------
522        ```py
523        value = Some(5)
524        print(value.is_some_and(lambda x: x > 3))
525        # True
526
527        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
528        print(value.is_some_and(lambda x: x > 3))
529        # False
530        ```
531        """
532        return self._value is not None and predicate(self._value)
533
534    def is_none(self) -> bool:
535        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `None`, otherwise returns `False`.
536
537        Example
538        -------
539        ```py
540        value = Some(5)
541        print(value.is_none())
542        # False
543
544        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
545        print(value.is_none())
546        # True
547        ```
548        """
549        return self._value is None
550
551    def __repr__(self) -> str:
552        if self._value is None:
553            return "None"
554        return f"Some({self._value!r})"
555
556    __str__ = __repr__
557
558    def __invert__(self) -> T:
559        return self.unwrap()
560
561    def __or__(self, other: T) -> T:
562        return self.unwrap_or(other)
563
564    def __bool__(self) -> bool:
565        return self.is_some()

567    def __eq__(self, other: object) -> bool:
568        if not isinstance(other, Some):
569            return NotImplemented
570
571        return self._value == other._value  # pyright: ignore[reportUnknownVariableType, reportUnknownMemberType]
572
573    def __ne__(self, other: object) -> bool:
574        return not self.__eq__(other)
575
576    def __hash__(self) -> int:
577        return hash(self._value)

The Option type. An object that might be T or None.

It is a drop-in replacement for typing.Optional[T], But has proper methods to handle the contained value.

Example
value = Some("Hello")
print(value)
# Some("Hello")

# This will unwrap the contained value as long as
# it is not `None` otherwise this will raise an error.
print(value.unwrap())
# "Hello"

none_value = Some(None)
while none_value.unwrap():
    # Never unreachable!

# Solving it with `unwrap_or` method to unwrap the value or return a default value.
print(none_value.unwrap_or(10))
# 10
Some(value: Optional[~T], /) 
85    def __init__(self, value: T | None, /) -> None:
86        self._value = value
@staticmethod
def default() -> None: 
88    @staticmethod
89    def default() -> None:
90        """Default value for `Some`. Returns `None`."""
91        return None

Default value for Some. Returns None.

 96        """Consume `Self`, returning the wrapped value as `T | None`.
 97
 98        Examples
 99        --------
100        ```py
101        opt = Some('char')
102        x = opt.into_inner()
103        assert x is not None
104
105        opt = Some(None)
106        assert opt.into_inner() is None
107        ```
108        """
109        return self._value

Consume Self, returning the wrapped value as T | None.

Examples

x = opt.into_inner()

assert opt.into_inner() is None
def unwrap(self) -> ~T: 
111    def unwrap(self) -> T:
112        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or raising a `RuntimeError`.
113
114        Example
115        -------
116        ```py
117        value = Some(5)
118        print(value.unwrap())
119        # 5
120
121        value = Some(None)
122        print(value.unwrap())
123        # RuntimeError
124        ```
125
126        Raises
127        ------
128        `RuntimeError`
129            If the inner value is `None`.
130        """
131        if self._value is None:
132            raise RuntimeError(
133                f"Called `Option.unwrap()` on {type(self._value).__name__}."
134            ) from None
135
136        return self._value

418        Example
419        -------
420        ```py
421        from sain import Some
422        value = Some("gg")
423        value.next() == Some("gg")

426        value.next().is_none()
427        ```

429        if self._value is None:
430            #! SAFETY: We know the value is None here.
431            return iter.empty()  # pyright: ignore
432
433        return iter.once(self._value)

def as_ref(self) -> Some[sain.cell.Cell[~T]]: 
435    def as_ref(self) -> Some[cell.Cell[T]]:
436        """Returns immutable `Some[sain.cell.Cell[T]]` if the contained value is not `None`,
437
438        Otherwise returns `Some(None)`.
439
440        Example
441        -------
442        ```py
443        value = Some(5).as_ref().unwrap()
444        value.object = 0 # FrozenError!
445
446        owned = value.object
447        print(owned) # 5
448
449        # Create a copy of object.
450        clone = value.copy()
451        clone = 0  # Thats fine.
452        print(clone == owned) # False, 0 != 5
453
454        # None object.
455        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
456        print(value.as_ref())
457        # Some(None)
458        ```
459
460        Raises
461        ------
462        `dataclasses.FrozenInstanceError`
463            When attempting to modify the contained value. Use `sain.AsRef.copy()` method to create a copy.
464
465            Or just use `.as_mut()` if you're dealing with mutable objects.
466        """
467        if self._value is not None:
468            return Some(cell.Cell(self._value))
469
470        # SAFETY: self._value is None.
471        return NOTHING  # pyright: ignore

Otherwise returns Some(None).

@typing.final
class Iter(sain.Iterator[~Item]): 
701@typing.final
702class Iter(Iterator[Item]):
703    """a lazy iterator that has its items ready in-memory.
704
705    This is similar to Rust `std::slice::Iter<T>` item which iterables can build
706    from this via `.iter()` method.
707
708    Example
709    -------
710    ```py
711    iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
712
713    # Limit the results to 2.
714    for item in iterator.take(2):
715        print(item)
716    # 1
717    # 2
718
719    # Filter the results.
720    for item in iterator.filter(lambda item: item > 1):
721        print(item)
722    # 2
723    # 3
724    # 3
725
726    # Indexing is supported.
727    print(iterator[0])
728    # 1
729    ```
730
731    Parameters
732    ----------
733    items: `Iterable[Item]`
734        The items to iterate over. This can be anything that implements `__iter__` and `__next__`.
735    """
736
737    __slots__ = ("_it",)
738
739    def __init__(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[Item]) -> None:
740        self._it = iter(iterable)
741
742    def clone(self) -> typing.Self:
743        """Return a copy of this iterator.
744
745        ```py
746        it = Iterator([1, 2, 3])
747
748        for i in it.clone():
749            ...
750
751        # The actual iterator hasn't been exhausted.
752        assert it.count() == 3
753        ```
754        """
755        return self.__class__(copy.copy(self._it))
756
757    def __next__(self) -> Item:
758        try:
759            return next(self._it)
760        except StopIteration:
761            unreachable()
762
763    def __getitem__(self, index: int) -> Option[Item]:
764        try:
765            return self.skip(index).first()
766        except IndexError:
767            unreachable()
768
769    # This is a never.
770    def __setitem__(self, _: None, __: None) -> typing.NoReturn:
771        raise NotImplementedError(
772            f"{type(self).__name__} doesn't support item assignment."
773        ) from None
774
775    def __contains__(self, item: Item) -> bool:
776        return item in self._it

This is similar to Rust std::slice::Iter<T> item which iterables can build from this via sain.iter() method.

class Iterator(typing.Generic[~Item], abc.ABC, sain.Default[~Item]): 
 87class Iterator(
 88    typing.Generic[Item],
 89    abc.ABC,
 90    _default.Default[Item],
 91):
 92    """An abstract interface for dealing with iterators.
 93
 94    This is exactly the same trait as `core::iter::Iterator` trait from Rust.
 95
 96    This is the main interface that any type can implement by basically inheriting from it.
 97    The method `__next__` is the only method that needs to be implemented, You get all the other methods for free.
 98
 99    If you want to use a ready iterator for general purposes, Use `Iter`. This interface is only for implementors
100    and type hints.
101
102    Example
103    -------
104    ```py
105    @dataclass
106    class Message:
107        content: str
108
109    class MessageIterator(sain.Iterator[Message]):
110        def __init__(self, id: int = random.randint(0, 100)) -> None:
111            self._session: requests.Session | None = None
112            self.id = id
113
114        def __next__(self) -> Message:
115            if self._session is None:
116                self._session = requests.session()
117
118            try:
119                with self._session:
120                    response = self._session.get(f"https://dummyjson.com/products/{self.id}").json()
121            finally:
122                self._session = None
123
124            return Message(response["description"])
125
126    it = MessageIterator()
127    # Lazily fetch the first 5 messages from the API.
128    for msg in it.take(5):
129        print(msg)
130    ```
131    """
132
133    @abc.abstractmethod
134    def __next__(self) -> Item:
135        raise NotImplementedError
136
137    ###################
138    # const functions #
139    ###################
140
141    @staticmethod
142    @typing.final
143    def default() -> Empty[Item]:
144        """Return the default iterator for this type. It returns an empty iterator.
145
146        Example
147        -------
148        ```py
149        it: Iterator[int] = Iter.default()
150        assert t.next().is_none()
151        ```
152        """
153        return Empty()
154
155    @typing.overload
156    @typing.final
157    def collect(self) -> collections.Sequence[Item]: ...
158
159    @typing.overload
160    @typing.final
161    def collect(
162        self, *, cast: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem]
163    ) -> collections.Sequence[OtherItem]: ...
164
165    @typing.final
166    def collect(
167        self, *, cast: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem] | None = None
168    ) -> collections.Sequence[Item] | collections.Sequence[OtherItem]:
169        """Collects all items in the iterator into an immutable sequence.
170
171        Example
172        -------
173        ```py
174        iterator = Iter(range(3))
175        iterator.collect()
176        # (0, 1, 2, 3)
177        iterator.collect(cast=str) # Map each element and collect it.
178        # ('0', '1', '2', '3')
179        ```
180
181        Parameters
182        ----------
183        cast: `T | None`
184            An optional type to cast the items into.
185            If not provided the items will be returned as it's original type.
186        """
187        if cast is not None:
188            return tuple(cast(i) for i in self)
189
190        return tuple(_ for _ in self)
191
192    @typing.final
193    def to_vec(self) -> Vec[Item]:
194        """Convert this iterator into `Vec[T]`.
195
196        Example
197        -------
198        ```py
199        it = sain.iter.once(0)
200        vc = it.to_vec()
201
202        assert to_vec == [0]
203        ```
204        """
205        return Vec(_ for _ in self)
206
207    @typing.final
208    def sink(self) -> None:
209        """Consume all elements from this iterator, flushing it into the sink.
210
211        Example
212        -------
213        ```py
214        it = Iter((1, 2, 3))
215        it.sink()
216        assert it.next().is_none()
217        ```
218        """
219        for _ in self:
220            pass
221
222    @typing.final
223    def raw_parts(self) -> collections.Generator[Item, None, None]:
224        """Decompose all elements from this iterator, yielding it one by one
225        as a normal generator.
226
227        This mainly used for objects that needs to satisfy its exact type.
228
229        ```py
230        it = Iter("cba")
231        sort = sorted(it.raw_parts())
232
233        assert it.count() == 0
234        assert sort == ["a", "b", "c"]
235        ```
236        """
237        for item in self:
238            yield item

244    def next(self) -> Option[Item]:
245        """Advance the iterator, Returning the next item, `Some(None)` if all items yielded.
246
247        Example
248        -------
249        ```py
250        iterator = Iter(["1", "2"])
251        assert iterator.next() == Some("1")
252        assert iterator.next() == Some("2")
253        assert iterator.next().is_none()
254        ```
255        """
256        try:
257            return _option.Some(self.__next__())
258        except StopIteration:
259            return _option.nothing_unchecked()
260
261    def cloned(self) -> Cloned[Item]:
262        """Creates an iterator which shallow copies its elements by reference.
263
264        If you need a copy of the actual iterator and not the elements.
265        use `Iter.clone()`
266
267        .. note::
268            This method calls [`copy.copy()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/copy.html)
269            on each item that is being yielded.
270
271        Example
272        -------
273        ```py
274        @dataclass
275        class User:
276            users_ids: list[int] = []
277
278        # An iterator which elements points to the same user.
279        user = User()
280        it = Iter((user, user))
281
282        for u in it.cloned():
283            u.user_ids.append(1)
284
285        # We iterated over the same user pointer twice and appended "1"
286        # since `copy` returns a shallow copy of nested structures.
287        assert len(user.user_ids) == 2
288        ```
289        """
290        return Cloned(self)
291
292    def copied(self) -> Copied[Item]:
293        """Creates an iterator which copies all of its elements by value.
294
295        If you only need a copy of the item reference, Use `.cloned()` instead.
296
297        .. note::
298            This method simply calls [`copy.deepcopy()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/copy.html)
299            on each item that is being yielded.
300
301        Example
302        -------
303        ```py
304        @dataclass
305        class User:
306            users_ids: list[int] = []
307
308        # An iterator which elements points to the same user.
309        user = User()
310        it = Iter((user, user))
311
312        for u in it.copied():
313            # A new list is created for each item.
314            u.user_ids.append(1)
315
316        # The actual list is untouched since we consumed a deep copy of it.
317        assert len(user.user_ids) == 0
318        ```
319        """
320        return Copied(self)
321
322    def map(self, fn: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem]) -> Map[Item, OtherItem]:
323        """Maps each item in the iterator to another type.
324
325        Example
326        -------
327        ```py
328        iterator = Iter(["1", "2", "3"]).map(int)
329
330        for item in iterator:
331            assert isinstance(item, int)
332        ```
333
334        Parameters
335        ----------
336        predicate: `Callable[[Item], OtherItem]`
337            The function to map each item in the iterator to the other type.
338        """
339        return Map(self, fn)

367            assert x in ('c', 'x')

370        ```

407    def take_while(self, f: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> TakeWhile[Item]:
408        """yields items from the iterator while predicate returns `True`.
409
410        The rest of the items are discarded as soon as the predicate returns `False`
411
412        Example
413        -------
414        ```py
415        iterator = Iter(['a', 'ab', 'xd', 'ba'])
416        for x in iterator.take_while(lambda x: 'a' in x):
417            print(x)
418
419        # a
420        # ab
421        ```
422
423        Parameters
424        ----------
425        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
426            The function to predicate each item in the iterator.
427        """
428        return TakeWhile(self, f)

430    def drop_while(self, f: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> DropWhile[Item]:
431        """Yields items from the iterator while predicate returns `False`.
432
433        Example

436        iterator = Iter(['a', 'ab', 'xd', 'ba'])

447            The function to predicate each item in the iterator.

449        return DropWhile(self, f)

451    def all(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> bool:
452        """Return `True` if all items in the iterator match the predicate.
453
454        Example
455        -------
456        ```py
457        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
458        while iterator.all(lambda item: isinstance(item, int)):
459            print("Still all integers")
460            continue
461            # Still all integers
462        ```
463
464        Parameters
465        ----------
466        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
467            The function to test each item in the iterator.

469        return all(predicate(item) for item in self)

471    def any(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> bool:
472        """`True` if any items in the iterator match the predicate.
473
474        Example
475        -------
476        ```py
477        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
478        if iterator.any(lambda item: isinstance(item, int)):
479            print("At least one item is an int.")
480        # At least one item is an int.
481        ```

484        ----------
485        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
486            The function to test each item in the iterator.
487        """
488        return any(predicate(item) for item in self)

490    def zip(
491        self, other: collections.Iterable[OtherItem]
492    ) -> Iterator[tuple[Item, OtherItem]]:
493        """Zips the iterator with another iterable.
494
495        Example
496        -------
497        ```py
498        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
499        for item, other_item in iterator.zip([4, 5, 6]):
500            assert item == other_item

511        `Iter[tuple[Item, OtherItem]]`

514        """

517    def sort(
518        self,
519        *,
520        key: collections.Callable[[Item], _typeshed.SupportsRichComparison],
521        reverse: bool = False,
522    ) -> Iterator[Item]:
523        """Sorts the iterator.
524
525        Example
526        -------
527        ```py
528        iterator = Iter([3, 1, 6, 7])
529        for item in iterator.sort(key=lambda item: item < 3):
530            print(item)
531        # 1
532        # 3
533        # 6
534        # 7
535        ```
536
537        Parameters
538        ----------
539        key: `collections.Callable[[Item], Any]`
540            The function to sort by.
541        reverse: `bool`
542            Whether to reverse the sort.
543
544        """
545        return Iter(sorted(self.raw_parts(), key=key, reverse=reverse))

547    def reversed(self) -> Iterator[Item]:
548        """Returns a new iterator that yields the items in the iterator in reverse order.
549
550        Example
551        -------
552        ```py
553        iterator = Iter([3, 1, 6, 7])
554        for item in iterator.reversed():
555            print(item)
556        # 7
557        # 6
558        # 1
559        # 3
560        ```
561        """
562        # NOTE: In order to reverse the iterator we need to
563        # first collect it into some collection.
564        return Iter(reversed(self.collect()))

566    def union(self, other: collections.Iterable[Item]) -> Iterator[Item]:
567        """Returns a new iterator that yields all items from both iterators.
568
569        Example
570        -------
571        ```py
572        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
573        other = [4, 5, 6]
574
575        for item in iterator.union(other):
576            print(item)
577        # 1
578        # 2
579        # 3
580        # 4
581        # 5
582        # 6
583        ```
584
585        Parameters
586        ----------
587        other: `Iter[Item]`
588            The iterable to union with.
589        """
590        return Iter(itertools.chain(self.raw_parts(), other))

592    def first(self) -> Option[Item]:

602        return self.take(1).next()

604    def last(self) -> Option[Item]:

608        -------
609        ```py
610        iterator = Iter([3, 1, 6, 7])
611        iterator.last().is_some_and(lambda x: x == 7)
612        ```
613        """
614        return self.reversed().first()
615
616    def count(self) -> int:
617        """Return the count of elements in memory this iterator has.
618
619        Example
620        -------
621        ```py
622        it = Iter(range(3))
623        assert it.count() == 3
624        ```
625        """
626        count = 0
627        for _ in self:
628            count += 1
629
630        return count
631
632    def for_each(self, func: collections.Callable[[Item], typing.Any]) -> None:
633        """Calls `func` on each item in the iterator.
634
635        Example
636        -------
637        ```py
638        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
639        iterator.for_each(lambda item: print(item))
640        # 1
641        # 2
642        # 3
643        ```
644
645        Parameters
646        ----------
647        func: `collections.Callable[[Item], typing.Any]`
648            The function to call on each item in the iterator.
649        """
650        for item in self:
651            func(item)
652
653    async def async_for_each(
654        self,
655        func: collections.Callable[
656            [Item], collections.Coroutine[None, typing.Any, OtherItem]
657        ],
658    ) -> _result.Result[collections.Sequence[OtherItem], futures.SpawnError]:
659        """Calls the async function on each item in the iterator concurrently.
660
661        Example
662        -------
663        ```py
664        async def create_user(username: str) -> None:
665            async with aiohttp.request("POST", f'.../{username}') as r:
666                return await r.json()
667
668        async def main():
669            users = sain.into_iter(["danny", "legalia"])
670            results = await users.async_for_each(lambda username: create_user(username))
671            for k, v in results.unwrap().items():
672                ...
673        ```
674
675        Parameters
676        ----------
677        func: `collections.Callable[[Item], Coroutine[None, Any, Any]]`
678            The async function to call on each item in the iterator.
679        """
680        return await futures.spawn(*(func(item) for item in self))
681
682    def __reversed__(self) -> Iterator[Item]:
683        return self.reversed()
684
685    def __repr__(self) -> str:
686        return f"<Iter(ptr: {hex(id(self))})>"
687
688    def __copy__(self) -> Cloned[Item]:
689        return self.cloned()
690
691    def __deepcopy__(self) -> Copied[Item]:
692        return self.copied()
693
694    def __len__(self) -> int:
695        return self.count()
696
697    def __iter__(self) -> Iterator[Item]:
698        return self

An abstract interface for dealing with iterators.

This is exactly the same trait as core::iter::Iterator trait from Rust.

This is the main interface that any type can implement by basically inheriting from it. The method __next__ is the only method that needs to be implemented, You get all the other methods for free.

If you want to use a ready iterator for general purposes, Use Iter. This interface is only for implementors and type hints.

Example
@dataclass
class Message:
    content: str

class MessageIterator(sain.Iterator[Message]):
    def __init__(self, id: int = random.randint(0, 100)) -> None:
        self._session: requests.Session | None = None
        self.id = id

    def __next__(self) -> Message:
        if self._session is None:
            self._session = requests.session()

        try:
            with self._session:
                response = self._session.get(f"https://dummyjson.com/products/{self.id}").json()
        finally:
            self._session = None

        return Message(response["description"])

it = MessageIterator()
# Lazily fetch the first 5 messages from the API.
for msg in it.take(5):
    print(msg)

@typing.final
def collect( self, *, cast: collections.abc.Callable[[~Item], ~OtherItem] | None = None) -> collections.abc.Sequence[~Item] | collections.abc.Sequence[~OtherItem]: 
165    @typing.final
166    def collect(
167        self, *, cast: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem] | None = None
168    ) -> collections.Sequence[Item] | collections.Sequence[OtherItem]:
169        """Collects all items in the iterator into an immutable sequence.
170
171        Example
172        -------
173        ```py
174        iterator = Iter(range(3))
175        iterator.collect()
176        # (0, 1, 2, 3)
177        iterator.collect(cast=str) # Map each element and collect it.
178        # ('0', '1', '2', '3')
179        ```
180
181        Parameters
182        ----------
183        cast: `T | None`
184            An optional type to cast the items into.
185            If not provided the items will be returned as it's original type.
186        """
187        if cast is not None:
188            return tuple(cast(i) for i in self)
189
190        return tuple(_ for _ in self)

@typing.final
def raw_parts(self) -> collections.abc.Generator[~Item, None, None]: 
222    @typing.final
223    def raw_parts(self) -> collections.Generator[Item, None, None]:
224        """Decompose all elements from this iterator, yielding it one by one

def next(self) -> 'Option[Item]': 
244    def next(self) -> Option[Item]:
245        """Advance the iterator, Returning the next item, `Some(None)` if all items yielded.
246
247        Example
248        -------
249        ```py
250        iterator = Iter(["1", "2"])
251        assert iterator.next() == Some("1")
252        assert iterator.next() == Some("2")
253        assert iterator.next().is_none()
254        ```
255        """
256        try:
257            return _option.Some(self.__next__())
258        except StopIteration:
259            return _option.nothing_unchecked()

def cloned(self) -> sain.iter.Cloned[~Item]: 
261    def cloned(self) -> Cloned[Item]:
262        """Creates an iterator which shallow copies its elements by reference.
263
264        If you need a copy of the actual iterator and not the elements.
265        use `Iter.clone()`
266
267        .. note::
268            This method calls [`copy.copy()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/copy.html)
269            on each item that is being yielded.
270
271        Example
272        -------
273        ```py
274        @dataclass
275        class User:
276            users_ids: list[int] = []
277
278        # An iterator which elements points to the same user.
279        user = User()
280        it = Iter((user, user))
281
282        for u in it.cloned():
283            u.user_ids.append(1)
284
285        # We iterated over the same user pointer twice and appended "1"
286        # since `copy` returns a shallow copy of nested structures.
287        assert len(user.user_ids) == 2
288        ```
289        """
290        return Cloned(self)

Creates an iterator which shallow copies its elements by reference.

If you need a copy of the actual iterator and not the elements. use Iter.clone()

This method calls copy.copy() on each item that is being yielded.

Example
@dataclass
class User:
    users_ids: list[int] = []

# An iterator which elements points to the same user.
user = User()
it = Iter((user, user))

for u in it.cloned():
    u.user_ids.append(1)

# We iterated over the same user pointer twice and appended "1"
# since `copy` returns a shallow copy of nested structures.
assert len(user.user_ids) == 2
def copied(self) -> sain.iter.Copied[~Item]: 
292    def copied(self) -> Copied[Item]:
293        """Creates an iterator which copies all of its elements by value.
294
295        If you only need a copy of the item reference, Use `.cloned()` instead.
296
297        .. note::
298            This method simply calls [`copy.deepcopy()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/copy.html)
299            on each item that is being yielded.
300
301        Example
302        -------
303        ```py
304        @dataclass
305        class User:
306            users_ids: list[int] = []
307
308        # An iterator which elements points to the same user.
309        user = User()
310        it = Iter((user, user))
311
312        for u in it.copied():
313            # A new list is created for each item.
314            u.user_ids.append(1)
315
316        # The actual list is untouched since we consumed a deep copy of it.
317        assert len(user.user_ids) == 0
318        ```
319        """
320        return Copied(self)

Creates an iterator which copies all of its elements by value.

If you only need a copy of the item reference, Use .cloned() instead.

This method simply calls copy.deepcopy() on each item that is being yielded.

Example
@dataclass

    users_ids: list[int] = []

# An iterator which elements points to the same user.
user = User()
it = Iter((user, user))

for u in it.copied():
    # A new list is created for each item.
    u.user_ids.append(1)

# The actual list is untouched since we consumed a deep copy of it.
assert len(user.user_ids) == 0

async def async_for_each( self, func: collections.abc.Callable[[~Item], collections.abc.Coroutine[None, typing.Any, ~OtherItem]]) -> Union[Ok[collections.abc.Sequence[~OtherItem]], Err[sain.futures.SpawnError]]:

def deprecated( *, since: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, removed_in: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, use_instead: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, hint: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None) -> 'collections.Callable[[collections.Callable[P, U]], collections.Callable[P, U]]': 
152def deprecated(
153    *,
154    since: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
155    removed_in: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
156    use_instead: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
157    hint: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
158) -> collections.Callable[
159    [collections.Callable[P, U]],
160    collections.Callable[P, U],
161]:
162    """A decorator that marks a function as deprecated.
163
164    An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.
165
166    Example
167    -------
168    ```py
169    from sain import deprecated
170
171    @deprecated(
172        since = "1.0.0",
173        removed_in ="3.0.0",
174        use_instead = "UserImpl()",
175        hint = "Hint for ux."
176    )
177    class User:
178        ...
179
180    user = User() # This will cause a warning at runtime.
181    ```
182
183    Parameters
184    ----------
185    since : `str`
186        The version that the function was deprecated.
187    removed_in : `str | None`
188        If provided, It will log when will the object will be removed in.
189    use_instead : `str | None`
190        If provided, This should be the alternative object name that should be used instead.
191    hint: `str`
192        An optional hint for the user.
193    """
194
195    def _create_message(obj: typing.Any) -> str:
196        msg = f"{_obj_type(obj)} `{obj.__module__}.{obj.__name__}` is deprecated."
197
198        if since is not None:
199            msg += f" since {since}."
200
201        if removed_in:
202            msg += f" Scheduled for removal in `{removed_in}`."
203
204        if use_instead is not None:
205            msg += f" Use `{use_instead}` instead."
206
207        if hint:
208            msg += f" Hint: {hint}"
209        return msg
210
211    def decorator(func: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
212        message = _create_message(func)
213
214        @functools.wraps(func)
215        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
216            _warn(message)
217            return func(*args, **kwargs)
218
219        # idk why pyright doesn't know the type of wrapper.
220        m = f"\n# Warning ⚠️\n{message}."
221        if wrapper.__doc__:
222            # append this message to an existing document.
223            wrapper.__doc__ = inspect.cleandoc(wrapper.__doc__) + f"{m}"
224        else:
225            wrapper.__doc__ = m
226        return wrapper
227
228    return decorator

def unimplemented( *, message: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, available_in: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None) -> 'collections.Callable[[collections.Callable[P, U]], collections.Callable[P, U]]': 
252def unimplemented(
253    *,
254    message: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
255    available_in: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
256) -> collections.Callable[
257    [collections.Callable[P, U]],
258    collections.Callable[P, U],
259]:
260    """A decorator that marks an object as unimplemented.
261
262    An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.
263
264    Example
265    -------
266    ```py
267    from sain import unimplemented
268
269    @unimplemented("User object is not implemented yet.")
270    class User:
271        ...
272    ```
273
274    Parameters
275    ----------
276    message : `str | None`
277        An optional message to be displayed when the function is called. Otherwise default message will be used.
278    available_in : `str | None`
279        If provided, This will be shown as what release this object be implemented.
280    """
281
282    def _create_message(obj: typing.Any) -> str:
283        msg = (
284            message
285            or f"{_obj_type(obj)} `{obj.__module__}.{obj.__name__}` is not yet implemented."
286        )  # noqa: W503
287
288        if available_in:
289            msg += f" Available in `{available_in}`."
290        return msg
291
292    def decorator(obj: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
293        message = _create_message(obj)
294
295        @functools.wraps(obj)
296        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
297            _warn(message)
298            return obj(*args, **kwargs)
299
300        # idk why pyright doesn't know the type of wrapper.
301        m = f"\n# Warning ⚠️\n{message}."
302        if wrapper.__doc__:
303            # append this message to an existing document.
304            wrapper.__doc__ = inspect.cleandoc(wrapper.__doc__) + f"{m}"
305        else:
306            wrapper.__doc__ = m
307        return wrapper
308
309    return decorator

def doc( path: 'Read') -> 'collections.Callable[[collections.Callable[P, U]], collections.Callable[P, U]]': 
312def doc(
313    path: Read,
314) -> collections.Callable[
315    [collections.Callable[P, U]],
316    collections.Callable[P, U],
317]:
318    """Set `path` to be the object's documentation.
319
320    Example
321    -------
322    ```py
323    from sain import doc
324    from pathlib import Path
325
326    @doc(Path("../README.md"))
327    class User:
328
329        @doc("bool.html")
330        def bool_docs() -> None:
331            ...
332    ```
333
334    Parameters
335    ----------
336    path: `type[int] | type[str] | type[bytes] | type[PathLike[str]] | type[PathLike[bytes]]`
337        The path to read the content from.
338    """
339
340    def decorator(f: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
341        with open(path, "r") as file:
342            f.__doc__ = file.read()
343
344        @functools.wraps(f)
345        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
346            return f(*args, **kwargs)
347
348        return wrapper
349
350    return decorator

129class Ok(typing.Generic[T]):
130    """Contains the success value of `Result[T, ...]`."""
131
132    _inner: T

134    ###############################
135    # * Boolean operations. * #
136    ###############################
137
138    def is_ok(self) -> typing.Literal[True]:
139        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Ok` and `False` if it an `Err`.
140
141        Example
142        -------
143        ```py
144        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
145        assert value.is_ok() == True
146        ```
147        """
148        return True
149
150    def is_ok_and(self, f: F[T, bool]) -> bool:
151        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Ok` and `f()` returns True..
152
153        Example
154        -------
155        ```py
156        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
157
158        assert value.is_ok_and(lambda inner: inner == "value")
159        # True
160        ```
161        """
162        return self.is_ok() and f(self._inner)
163
164    # These are never truthy in an `Ok` instance.
165    def is_err(self) -> typing.Literal[False]:
166        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Err`.
167
168        Example
169        -------
170        ```py
171        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
172
173        assert value.is_err() == False
174        ```
175        """
176        return False
177
178    def is_err_and(self, f: F[T, bool]) -> typing.Literal[False]:
179        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Ok` and `f()` returns True..
180
181        Example
182        -------
183        ```py
184        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
185
186        assert value.is_err_and(lambda inner: inner == "value")
187        # False
188        ```
189        """
190        return False

196    def expect(self, message: str, /) -> T:
197        """Return the underlying value if it was `Ok`, Raising `RuntimeError`
198        if it was `Err` with `message` passed to it.
199
200        Example
201        -------
202        ```py
203        ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("owo")
204        ok.expect("err") # owo
205
206        err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
207        err.expect("err") # RuntimeError("err")
208        ```
209        """
210        return self._inner
211
212    def unwrap(self) -> T:
213        """Return the underlying value if it was `Ok`, Raising `RuntimeError` if it was `Err`.
214
215        Example
216        -------
217        ```py
218        ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("owo")
219        ok.unwrap() # owo
220
221        err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
222        err.unwrap() # RuntimeError
223        ```
224        """
225        return self._inner
226
227    def unwrap_or(self, default: T, /) -> T:
228        """Return the underlying value if it was `Ok`, returning `default` if it was `Err`.
229
230        Example
231        -------
232        ```py
233        ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("OwO")
234        ok.unwrap_or("uwu") # OwO
235
236        err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
237        err.unwrap_or("uwu") # uwu
238        ```
239        """
240        return self._inner
241
242    def unwrap_or_else(self, f: F[E, T]) -> T:
243        """Return the contained `Ok` value or computes it from `f()` if it was `Err`.
244
245        Example
246        -------
247        ```py
248        ok: Result[int, str] = Ok(4)
249        ok.unwrap_or_else(lambda e: 0) # 4
250
251        err: Result[int, str] = Err("word")
252        err.unwrap_or_else(lambda e: len(e)) # 4
253        ```
254        """
255        return self._inner
256
257    def unwrap_err(self) -> typing.NoReturn:
258        """Return the contained `Err` value, Raising if it was `Ok`.
259
260        Example
261        -------
262        ```py
263        ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("buh")
264        ok.unwrap_err()  # RuntimeError
265
266        err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
267        err.unwrap_err() == None
268        # True
269        ```
270        """
271        raise RuntimeError(f"Called `unwrap_err` on an `Ok` variant: {self._inner!r}")
272
273    ############################
274    # * Conversion adapters. * #
275    ############################
276
277    def ok(self) -> Option[T]:
278        """Convert `Ok[T]` to `Option[T]` if the contained value was `Ok` and `Option[None]` if it was `Err`.
279
280        Example
281        -------
282        ```py
283        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("buh")
284        value.ok().is_some() # True
285
286        value: Result[str, int] = Err(0)
287        value.ok().is_none() # True
288        ```
289        """
290        return _option.Some(self._inner)
291
292    def err(self) -> Option[None]:
293        """Convert `Err[T]` to `Option[T]` if the contained value was `Err` and `Option[None]` if it was `Ok`.
294
295        Example
296        -------
297        ```py
298        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("buh")
299        value.err().is_none() # True
300
301        value: Result[str, int] = Err(0)
302        value.err().is_some() # True
303        ```
304        """
305        return _option.NOTHING
306
307    def inspect(self, f: F[T, typing.Any]) -> None:
308        """Call a function to the contained value if it was `Ok` and do nothing if it was `Err`
309
310        Example
311        -------
312        ```py
313        def sink(value: str) -> None:
314            # do something with value
315            print("Called " + value)

317        x: Result[str, None] = Ok("ok")

319
320        x: Result[str, str] = Err("err")
321        x.inspect(sink) # None
322        ```
323        """
324        f(self._inner)
325
326    def inspect_err(self, f: F[E, typing.Any]) -> None:
327        """Call a function to the contained value if it was `Err` and do nothing if it was `Ok`
328
329        Example

341        ```
342        """
343
344    def map(self, f: F[T, U], /) -> Ok[U]:
345        """Map `Ok[T]` to `Ok[U]` by applying a function to `T`, Leaving `Err` untouched.
346
347        Example
348        -------
349        ```py
350        ok: Result[str, int] = Ok("1")
351        ok.map(lambda c: int(c) + 1) # Ok(2)
352
353        err: Result[str, int] = Err(0)
354        err.map(str.upper) # Err(0)
355        ```
356        """
357        return Ok(f(self._inner))
358
359    def map_or(self, f: F[T, U], default: U, /) -> U:
360        """Returns the provided default value if `Err`,
361
362        Otherwise extracts the `Ok` value and maps it to `f()`
363
364        Example
365        -------
366        ```py
367        x: Result[str, str] = Ok("foo")
368        assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 3
369
370        x: Result[str, str] = Err("bar")
371        assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 42
372        ```
373        """
374        return f(self._inner)
375
376    def map_or_else(self, f: F[T, U], default: F[E, U], /) -> U:
377        """Returns the provided default value from a function if `Err`,
378
379        Otherwise extracts the `Ok` value and maps it to `f()`
380
381        Example
382        -------
383        ```py
384        x: Result[str, str] = Ok("four")
385        assert x.map_or_else(
386            lambda c: 2 * len(c),
387            lambda err: len(err)
388        ) == 8

390        x: Result[str, str] = Err("bar")
391        assert x.map_or_else(
392            lambda c: 2 * len(c),
393            lambda err: len(err)
394        ) == 3
395        ```
396        """
397        return f(self._inner)
398
399    def map_err(self, f: F[E, U], /) -> Self:
400        """Maps a `Result[T, E]` to `Result[T, U]`, leaving `OK[T]` untouched.
401
402        Example
403        -------
404        ```py
405        x: Result[str, int] = Ok("blue")
406        x.map_err(lambda err: err + 1) # Ok("blue")
407
408        x: Result[str, int] = Err(5)
409        x.map_err(float) # Err(5.0)
410        ```
411        """
412        return self

436        return _iter.once(self._inner)

218        ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("owo")
219        ok.unwrap() # owo
220
221        err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
222        err.unwrap() # RuntimeError
223        ```
224        """
225        return self._inner

Return the underlying value if it was Ok, Raising RuntimeError if it was Err.

Example
ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("owo")
ok.unwrap() # owo

err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
err.unwrap() # RuntimeError
